Rich - 

Repatination of tsuba can be done--correctly--but refinishing such=
 as removing pits, etc., no, I don't think anyone would want to do that. So=
metimes a terrific tsuba is found that has been buffed or whatever and then=
, repatination can be done to save it. Skip Holbrook used to do this but to=
day--if I understand things correctly--only handles really high quality tsu=
ba. We all experiement with repatination I'm sure, but care must be taken n=
ot to (further) damage an important quality tsuba. 

Several years ago a Ja=
panese  gentleman (artist) was at one of the sword shows displaying his pri=
ze-winning newly made tsuba. His tsuba were traditionally made and quite be=
atufiul...and quite expensive! So there are those around today who continue=
 the craft.

Ron
STL

  We would not exp=
ect you to be able to restore tsuba LOL.

  Rich
